;;朱莉·德沃尔;

;

;欢迎收看今天的《哈佛商业评论》快速报道。我是 Julie Devoll，哈佛商业评论特别项目和网络研讨会的编辑。今天我们采访的是 SAP SuccessFactors 的首席营销和解决方案官 Aaron Green。

;

;;Aaron Green;

;

;嘿，朱莉。感谢您邀请我来到这里。

;

;;朱莉·德沃尔;

;
;
;
; ;
;
;
;

;嗨，亚伦。非常感谢您今天加入我们。让我们开始吧。

;

;当今的组织面临着许多挑战，无论是市场动态的变化还是劳动力短缺。他们如何才能在当今的环境中并着眼于未来取得成功？有哪些障碍？他们如何前进？

;

;;亚伦·格林;

;

;是的，绝对如此。朱莉，我认为当今组织面临的首要问题或挑战实际上可能是技能差距本身。这是我们所有客户真正关心的事情。事实上，技能是未来工作的新货币。

;

;这从根本上意味着我们需要重新思考留住和吸引人才以及在正确的时间寻找正确的技能的方式在组织中。在最近的一项调查中，超过 75% 的企业领导者表示，雇用和留住人才是实现增长的头号最关键因素。我们知道，我们的员工是任何组织所拥有的最宝贵的资产。我们的员工使我们能够创新、竞争和成长。

;

;因此，这对组织来说意味着我们必须能够了解我们今天拥有的技能，但也了解这些技能未来需要的。并制定提升技能、交叉技能、重新技能的计划，并在某些情况下从外部市场引入这些技能。这确实是任何公司，尤其是成长型或规模化公司，都需要思考如何看待人才。

;

;;朱莉·德沃尔;

;

;所以我想稍微转向一下工具和流程。当组织致力于使用不同的工具在其所有实践中分享见解和情报时，员工如何体验这种变化？

;
;
;
; ;
;
;
;

; ;亚伦·格林;

;

;是的。因此，我们知道，为了提供非凡的客户体验或客户成果，您确实必须拥有非凡的员工体验（雇主和员工的价值主张），因为当您这样做时，当您真正关注员工时，您的人们最终会获得更有意义的工作经历。无论您身处哪个行业或地区，这些都会转化为更高的生产力和更好的客户体验。

;

;但这实际上意味着您必须实时了解所有员工类型的劳动力总数，包括您的临时劳动力，因为这些见解可以让您真正了解您的员工拥有的技能、他们的愿望、他们的工作偏好以及他们的表现。它确实可以让组织将其与未来的劳动力相匹配，并确保您的员工了解组织未来发展计划的路径。

;

;;朱莉·德沃尔;

;

;所以我想展望未来。您如何看待人工智能和自动化帮助组织以目前无法真正做到的方式提高这些洞察力和效率？

;

;;亚伦·格林;

;

;是的。因此，毫无疑问，人工智能是目前的超级热门话题。 SAP SuccessFactors 拥有超过 9,600 名客户，每天与超过 2.5 亿唯一用户合作，我们对此深感荣幸。我们的客户一直在与我们谈论人工智能。事实上，在我们最近所做的一项研究中，我们发现招聘和学习是组织考虑如何投资人工智能以真正实现当今所需的许多手动任务自动化的两个最优先领域。

;

;但是有一些新兴的用例，比如用于更复杂的管理任务的聊天机器人或人力资源自助服务或票务，还有人工智能来推动我们已经讨论过的一些内部流动性，着眼于技能个人资料和职业道路，并利用它来实际将人员与组织内部的机会相匹配，无论他们是短期角色、零工还是长期角色。但从根本上讲，这意味着人工智能驱动的人才情报平台对于所有组织（无论是人力资源还是更广泛的员工群体）都将变得比以往更加重要。

;

;;Julie Devoll;

;

;嗯，亚伦，这是一次很棒的谈话。非常感谢您今天加入我们。

;

;;亚伦·格林;

;

;感谢您邀请我。

;
;

;;作者：Aaron Green;

;

;在当今的竞争格局中，员工是组织脱颖而出的关键。他们独特的技能、经验和贡献帮助公司创新、竞争和成长。

;

;不过，由于技术和创新引入的速度，组织所需的技能在不断变化。事实上，经济合作与发展组织估计技术将颠覆;未来五年将创造 11 亿个就业岗位; — 使技能差距成为以增长为重点的组织面临的最大障碍之一今天。

;

;解决这些差距首先要弄清楚您现在和将来需要哪些技能，以及您是否应该通过单独招聘或通过提升现有员工的技能、交叉技能和再培训来获得这些技能。

;

; p>;

;所有组织（尤其是注重增长的组织）都需要采用基于技能的方法来看待人才。但要实现这一点，您需要专为这项工作而构建的技术。如果没有它，人力资源和招聘团队就缺乏集成的实时数据框架，这意味着他们更多地根据直觉而不是数据驱动的证据做出决策。

;

;考虑到以增长为重点的组织面临的许多挑战如今，例如快速变化的市场条件、保持员工生产力和敬业度的需要，以及吸引顶尖人才的竞争，拥有合适的人力资源技术来满足您的业务和员工不断变化的需求可以改变游戏规则。

;

;互联的云人力资源和企业资源规划 (ERP) 方法有助于将数据从孤岛中解放出来，以便所有部门都可以实时访问相同的人员数据。这可以提高效率和生产力，降低运营成本和违规风险，改善人们的工作体验，并帮助组织将具备所需技能的人员分配到合适的角色。

;
;
;
; ;
;
;
;

;;将人置于业务转型的核心;

;

;投资于这项技术意味着投资于您的员工——而人是推动业务转型的动力。如今，人们期望员工体验 (EX) 中的每次互动都像网上购物一样轻松、无缝且个性化。通过使用技术来增强 EX（从自动化耗时的流程到提供个性化的学习建议），人们可以获得更有意义的工作体验，从而转化为更积极的员工队伍、更高的生产力和更好的业务成果。

;

;公司例如 ;MOD 披萨;，;Growmark;，以及;Sun 社区;是一个很好的例子，说明如何通过加强人力资源与业务运营之间的联系来关注以人为本推动增长。

;

;为了消除招聘和入职流程中的摩擦并使新员工更快地提高工作效率，MOD Pizza 的人力资源团队确定需要用可扩展的云来取代孤立的人员数据和手动流程基于技术。

;

;迁移到 HR 和 ERP 的单一云平台帮助 MOD Pizza 每月自动化 1,000 名员工的入职，以及与新员工、晋升和离职相关的每日 400 项事件变更，从而实现每周手动数据输入时间减少 15 小时。

;

;该公司还在招聘和入职体验中集成了调查接触点，以在员工生命周期的这一重要阶段收集反馈。这种互联方法正在帮助 MOD Pizza 提高整个业务的效率，同时改善 EX。

;

;农业企业合作社 ;Growmark; 管理 3,600 名内部员工的人力资源，并为其成员公司的另外 4,200 名员工提供薪资支持。通过迁移到基于云的解决方案来简化 HR 和 ERP 运营，帮助 Growmark 集成管理流程、提高整个业务的可见性并实现手动任务的自动化。结合人员和运营数据的分析有助于确保 Growmark 将员工置于绩效跟踪、风险规划和决策的中心。

;

;;Sun Communities; 是一家领先的制造住房社区和休闲车度假村的所有者和运营商，通过更换遗留下来的拼凑物，改变了其业务流程具有基于云的集成解决方案的工具。这有助于人力资源人员简化招聘、入职、绩效管理和薪资等流程和经验的管理，而无需依赖内部 IT 资源。

;
;
;
; ;
;
;
;

;像这样以增长为中心的组织需要确保其人力资源系统、经验和战略不会在脱节的状态下运行。理想的平台汇集了组织所需的人才、人口统计、经验和运营数据，以为其人力资源、财务、供应链和客户决策提供信息。通过这种连接，组织还可以用端到端自动化业务流程和改进的体验来取代传统和低效的流程。

;

;实时洞察您的员工总数并了解由此对您的影响业务，您可以为您的企业和员工释放新的机会。您可以深入了解员工的技能、愿望、偏好和绩效。此视图使您的业务需求与员工的需求、愿望和能力前所未有地保持一致。

;

;借助正确的云技术，当今以增长为重点的组织正在加强人力资源在整个行业中的联系。业务并在整个员工队伍中扩展个性化 EX。这些组织正在更智能地工作，更快地招聘，并为未来做好规划，这让他们的员工很高兴成为他们未来的一部分。

;

; ;摘要。   ; ;

;对于中小企业制造商来说，现在正是通过投资新软件和制造创新来升级运营的好时机。原因包括原始设备制造商面临建立更具弹性的供应链和区域化生产的压力，以及成本下降和新技术易用性的提高。本文介绍了中小企业采用这些技术可以采取的六个步骤。

; ;
;
;
;
;
; ;阅读西班牙语;
; ;Ler em português;
;

;疫情后推动供应链更具区域性和弹性，为许多国内中小企业创造了增长机会（大型原始设备制造商 (OEM) 所依赖的中小企业 (SME)。这些中小企业在 2000 年代的离岸外包浪潮中幸存下来，通常是因为它们为汽车、航空航天或工业设备行业生产产量较低或运输成本较高的零部件。但当增长不多时，投资新设备或设施对他们来说是一项挑战。现在，一些增长正在恢复，这些中小企业有机会采用新的软件和制造创新，并重新思考如何提高运营效率和生产力。

;

;过去三年我们与美国中西部的众多中小企业、贸易协会和美国政府支持的;制造推广合作伙伴关系 (MEP); 进行了交谈。 MEP 由国家标准研究院设立，旨在帮助中小企业制造商，遍布全美 50 个州和波多黎各。我们中的一位（Ali Shakouri）还与印第安纳州的中小企业进行了广泛的合作，;28.6%; 用于制造业的州生产总值比例最高。我们发现，这些公司在采用新技术方面往往相当保守，原因如下：

;
    ;
  • ;他们不愿意改变现有的有效流程，并且这些流程已经为他们提供了良好的服务。
    • ;
  • ;由于来自客户和外国竞争的持续成本压力，面对不断增长的需求或生产能力的限制，他们的投资兴趣有限。
    • ;
  • ;或者他们发现数字技术令人畏惧，因为需要学习新技能或开发新的工作方式。
    • ;
;

;这通常意味着他们没有跟上正在改变竞争格局的技术。在 2000 年代离岸外包热潮期间，许多制造商将大部分大批量生产转移到海外，对最新工具和技术的投资也转移到了海外。例如，在金属铸造行业，这一点很明显，因为在低成本国家建立了配备最新工具的新工厂。在熔模铸造领域，中国和印度的新工厂配备了最新的生产工具，而美国工厂则保留着旧的生产工具。当您成长时，投资最新技术是很容易的；当你没有的时候，更容易坚持你所拥有的。

;

;现在这样看待它是错误的——这实际上是投资的时刻。以下是六种入门方法。

;

;1.利用新的仿真软件工具。

;

;计算机辅助设计工具已经陪伴我们数十年，它们彻底改变了工程的所有分支 - 从机械零件和化学工艺到电子产品和半导体的所有设计和分析。然而，引人注目的是这些工具的日益复杂性以及软件开发人员为使它们更易于使用且更便宜而进行的投资。然而，中小企业的采用进展缓慢。

; ; ;
; ;
;
; 洞察中心集合
;

;运营新时代

;
; 提高效率并增强弹性。
;
; ;
; ; ;

;仿真建模工具可以成为改进操作的捷径。它们使公司能够更好地建模和理解其流程，这可以揭示瓶颈和约束，从而带来新的运营方式。这些工具在过去十年中在易用性方面取得了长足的进步，其中许多工具基于云，具有简单的拖放界面，并提供构建块，您可以合并这些构建块以使模型易于构建。更复杂的软件包提供了构建数字孪生的机会 - 一个逼真的运营数字模型，不仅包括机器和物料搬运系统，还包括在那里工作的人员。

;

;这是一家公司的一个很好的例子，仿真工具发挥了重要作用;Pelco Products;，一家位于俄克拉荷马州埃德蒙市的交通和公用事业产品（如路灯、电线杆）制造商和行人按钮。随着多年来的发展，其生产流程不断扩大并减慢了生产速度。为了改进它们，创始人的儿子 Steve Parduhn 引入了俄克拉荷马州制造联盟 (OMA)，即该州的 MEP。 Parduhn 在使用 ;Sketchup; 和 ;Simio;。这使得 Pelco 在开始移动设备之前可以虚拟地测试新场景。它甚至能够在将新技术和设备带到现场之前对其进行模拟。工厂产能的增加节省了 100 万美元的成本，并增加了 500 万美元的新销售额。

;

;2.将数据和新的分析技术投入使用。

;

;中小企业制造商经常从其运营中收集大量数据，但大多数没有利用新的人工智能 (AI)，包括机器学习 (ML) 工具来从数据中获得新的见解。对于没有经验的公司来说，这可能会令人生畏，因此关键是从简单开始并学习。

;

;与普渡大学的 ;AI-Commons 团队;，;TMF Center;，一家位于印第安纳州威廉斯波特的公司，安装了廉价的功耗传感器来确定复杂零件加工操作的使用模式。这帮助它开始对活动进行分类并开发商店绩效的实时仪表板。位于印第安纳州拉斐特的 ;Kirby Risk Manufacturing; 正在尝试使用声音传感器和机器学习来检测操作过程中的质量问题，这将允许它可以更快地识别和解决问题。

;

;同样，;Primient;，一家位于伊利诺伊州绍姆堡的食品配料公司，能够与普渡大学合作，为其拉斐特玉米甜味剂工厂开发一个简单的机器学习成像应用程序，帮助其操作员评估糖晶体尺寸分布的生产过程，该特征决定了晶体在食品中溶解的速度，因此它们尝起来多么甜啊。新的应用程序为以前需要操作员判断的过程提供了测量精度，该过程容易出现人为错误和广泛的变化。机器学习应用程序为其开始使用其广泛的生产数据来提高产量和运营效率奠定了基础。

;

;3.了解如何实现简单的自动化。

;

;虽然许多中小企业采用了一定程度的自动化，但通常采用预设包的形式，例如作为昂贵附加组件的一部分购买的自动工具交换系统或自动工件装载机- 机床。通常有许多“肮脏、乏味和危险”的工作仍然由手工完成，而自动化不仅可以通过减少变异性来提高产品质量，而且可以通过让工人解放出来在其他地方从事更有生产力和更理想的工作来改善工人的工作。的过程。但对于没有经验的中小企业来说，这些项目都是令人生畏的。同样，答案是从小项目开始，向欧洲议会议员等组织学习并获得帮助。

;

;俄克拉荷马州制造联盟副总裁 Kinnee Tilly 描述了该联盟如何帮助;Rise Manufacturing; 是一家位于俄克拉荷马州布罗肯阿罗的公司，为航空航天、国防和工业领域提供制造和组装服务。石油和天然气客户。疫情期间，Rise 的产品需求激增，导致其制造流程出现瓶颈。 “他们有一个手动抛光过程，人为差异正在悄然蔓延，”蒂莉解释道。 “我们有些人一生中从未接触过机器人之类的东西，他们对此非常警惕，因为他们觉得自己将被取代。” OMA 借给它一个;协作机器人;（“cobot”），这是一种轻型机械臂，编程简单，可以安全地与工作人员共享空间，以帮助 Rise 启动并运行流程。工人们看到了好处。 “一旦我们完成了，我们不仅没有取代员工，还提高了他们的技能，并让他们找到了更好的工作，”蒂莉说。

;

;4。了解生产工具和方法的最新进展。

;

;对于中小企业来说，了解其行业中使用的最新工具和流程对于加快生产周期和提高质量非常重要。例如，数字铸造技术涵盖模拟、打印原型、打印模具和激光计量，可以帮助降低成本，并使中小企业金属铸造厂能够更有效地与海上生产竞争。

;5。利用大学和外部资源的援助计划。

;

;MEP 计划旨在帮助中小企业提高能力并开始采用新技术。普渡大学负责管理印第安纳州的 MEP 和该州的;技术援助计划;，在采用新技术方面提供广泛的培训和服务。它甚至将中小企业与大学教职员工和学生联系起来，每年在各个领域提供长达 40 小时的帮助，包括先进过程控制、材料、故障分析、传感器使用和应用以及工程分析。

;

;

;时机

;

;现在是中小企业制造商投资自身转型的时机。建立更具弹性的供应链和生产区域化的压力为国内制造商提供了难得的增长机会，在此期间他们可以更新其运营和运营策略。他们不应该错过这个机会。

;
; ;
; < span>;总结。; ;

;一些消费者在单独使用时体验是最好的。但新的研究表明，人们会为了与伴侣或亲人分享而放弃高质量的体验。结果，他们的日子可能会更糟，从而导致消费者不满意、销售额下降和商机被忽视。本文解释了为什么人们倾向于团结在一起，即使这不一定有益，并概述了营销人员可以鼓励人们分开（即使是短暂的）以提高他们的满意度的几种方法。

; ;
;
;
;
;
; ;阅读en español;
; ;葡萄牙语;
;

;人们的生活通常是与他人共度美好时光和独处时间的结合。有些体验似乎是为了团聚 - 例如，;最近的估计;表明 90% 的电影院参观发生在电影院与其他人一起——而其他人则更适合独处时间，例如阅读或绘画。虽然人们经常自己决定如何度过自己的时间，但公司的选择也会影响这些决定。企业的设计或明或暗地旨在鼓励消费者与他人在一起或独处——例如每排有两个座位的游乐园游乐设施，或者提供吧台座位的餐厅，这样人们就不需要坐在空椅子旁的桌子旁在他们对面。

;

;这些决策对客户体验有什么影响？特别是，当人们面临两难境地时会发生什么：选择是在朋友或伴侣旁边体验某些事情，即使它可能会降低质量，还是获得更高质量的服务，但分开做？例如，决定是否在音乐会上选择远离舞台的两个相邻座位或在场地前排选择两个不相邻的座位，或者等待更长的时间与全家人一起去游乐园游乐设施

;

;;我们的研究最近发表在;期刊上消费者心理学;;的研究表明，消费者经常选择质量较低的服务，以便在活动期间与同伴保持身体距离。 People will select these lower-quality options even in situations that offer little opportunity for interaction (like a yoga class), even when they know they'll have plenty of togetherness time later (like taking a flight on the way to a long vacation together) — and even when companies specifically tell them that services are designed to be experienced solo.

;

;Consumers so value togetherness that they will choose less-pleasing experiences or even skip high-quality experiences just because they cannot be physically next to someone they care about. This can result in unsatisfied consumers, lower sales, and neglected business opportunities. Luckily, our research has also identified some strategies marketers can implement to encourage consumers to be apart from a companion if needed.

;

;Tradeoffs Between Togetherness and Quality

;

;To test the idea that people will choose social over solitary experiences, even when the latter may be more enjoyable, we first analyzed Tripadvisor reviews of the interactive play ;;Sleep No More;;. This is a unique experience in New York City: people who attend this play walk around several theatrically designed rooms reliving the classic Shakespearean tragedy ;Macbeth;. Importantly, this experience has been ;optimized for; ;aloneness;: the creators highlight that audience members should be silent, that people should walk at their own pace, and that staying with one's partner would create barriers between the audience and the actors.

;

;Yet, we observe that some visitors (45 out of the 312 reviews we coded) explicitly ignored these instructions and chose to stay with their companion, even though everyone was informed that they would meet their companion at the bar inside for an after-party discussion. What's more, visitors who stayed with their companion rated the experience lower on Tripadvisor, about 25% below that of those who went through the experience apart from their companion.

;

;We then conducted a series of experiments in lab and online settings to understand ;why; consumers prioritize togetherness with a partner over the quality of experience, asking people to make choices about chocolate, seats for a show, or spots for a class. For example, in one study that we conducted at the behavioral lab of Mays Business School at Texas A&M University, we asked students to make a choice about how many chocolates they would like to share with another participant: they could either get two chocolates (one per person) and eat them together or they could get four chocolates (two per person) and eat them apart. We found that more people chose the option of eating fewer chocolates with another person when instructed that their companion would be a new friend as opposed to a stranger.

;

;Ultimately, and perhaps unsurprisingly, we concluded that people want to remember experiences as shared with people they know, and they believe that physical proximity facilitates the creation of special memories. Many people even recognize that getting an experience of lower quality is in fact less enjoyable even when shared with someone else — and yet they still choose less-pleasing experiences to remember the activity as shared. This can pose a problem: ;research; by Erica J. Boothby and colleagues demonstrates that sharing an experience with someone enhances the enjoyment ;only; if the experience is positive to start off. Their theory suggests that when people share a negative experience (eg, they watch a bad movie together), they will perceive it as even ;more; unpleasant when engaging in the experience with someone else as opposed to alone.

;

;This creates a dilemma for marketers and customer experience managers: many people will explicitly ignore your attempts to activity something solo, which may be fine if they enjoy the product or service. But if they don't, their reaction will be even more negative because they shared it with someone else.

;

;Making Solo Experiences More Enjoyable

;

;If the experiences your company provides would benefit from consumers being solo (at least during a part of the activity), there are a few ways to encourage people to choose higher-quality experiences.

;

;Given consumers' reluctance to experience a perk without their partner enjoying the same perk, offering the same benefits to the companion of a recipient can be a way to increase people's uptake and satisfaction with any special treatment they are offered. This might look like offering an additional TSA Precheck pass to the spouse of a frequent traveler. However, it is not always possible for companies to treat their customers with free or discounted perks that will improve the overall experience because of monetary or space constraints. For example, an airline might not have two empty adjacent seats in first class. So, how should they communicate a free first-class upgrade to two people traveling together when the seats aren't next to each other?

;

;In these situations, framing an activity as functional is one way to spur people to be apart during experiences where physical proximity to one's partner would not necessarily maximize enjoyment. For example, a flight is one of many activities that people will share during a family vacation; thus, framing the flight as a utilitarian activity that serves the purpose of getting people to their final destination can be a way to encourage travelers to break apart to have a better experience. So instead of just saying, “Here's an upgrade on us!” when treating a couple with two first-class non-adjacent seats, our research suggests the airline should also mention, “Use the time during this flight to rest because your adventure starts the moment you step off the plane.”

;

;Finally, businesses could provide guidance for consumers to be together for some parts of an experience but also to indulge their own interests for part of the time. Think of a couple visiting an art museum: partners might perceive it as awkward or inappropriate to suggest that they split up at some point to see different exhibits, even though this would make them happier. However, the museum could suggest paths for parties visiting with a group to “divide and conquer” the museum by exploring different aspects of the collection. When the parties meet back up, they can share photos or descriptions of what they saw — enabling visitors to create special memories together of the experience.

;

;Our research can help marketers minimize complaints from customers whose shared experience is of lower quality by encouraging consumers to take advantage of more pleasant solo experiences — all while keeping some aspects of their social bond intact. These findings are especially relevant for activities where physical proximity does not always maximize enjoyment, like education or self-care. Recognizing that consumers often overvalue togetherness could result in better strategies for your organization and happier customers.

; ;
; ;
; ;Anton Vierietin/Getty Images;
;
; ;
; ;Summary.   ; ;

;If you’ve ever been in an unhealthy work situation, you probably know how hard it can be to leave. Leaving a bad job is never easy, and each person’s breaking point is different, so beating yourself up over why you stayed so long in a traumatic situation won’t help. But learning from each experience will empower you to own your career choices and leave earlier if you find yourself in a comparable situation again. The author presents five common reasons it’s hard to leave a bad job and strategies for moving on.

; ;
;
;
;
;
; ;Leer en español;
; ;Ler em português;
;

;Have you ever been in a bad employment situation but couldn't bring yourself to leave? Nearly every client tells me about trauma they experienced at work, whether it's an unsupportive or deliberately cruel manager, a company implementing policies that are unfavorable to employees, continuous layoffs creating stress and anxiety, or politics that left them feeling devalued.

;

;Yet they stayed, some for years, even though they knew their work environment wasn't healthy. Here are five reasons it's hard to leave a bad job — and what to do about them.

;

;Loyalty to your “work family”

;

;Working at a company for a long time can create a sense of loyalty to the organization and team members. My client, Beatrice (not her real name), worked for a law firm for more than 15 years and expected to be made a shareholder. But she learned she was rejected from partnership. “The lightbulb went off, and this was never going to be my company. I have given my life to these people, and they didn't value me that way. I had to decide, did I want to start over and try to become a shareholder somewhere else?” That was the breaking point for her, but even with an offer in hand from another firm where she would be a shareholder, she still struggled to depart. “I felt tremendous guilt leaving my old firm. I celebrated every major holiday with them. Two partners are my kids' godparents. It was like my family.” In the end, Beatrice weighed her loyalty to the firm against the firm's loyalty to her, which helped her decide to accept another firm's offer.

;

;What to do about it

;

;Recognize that companies hire you to use your skills and capabilities to provide a service. If you're no longer providing the value the company expects or the company changes its goals and your skills are no longer needed, the company will let you go.

;

;Now, reverse that logic. Look at how you're serving the company through the lens of what ;you ;need to feel fulfilled and valued in your job. Determine if the company is still providing the value to your life that you need and deserve.

;

;Some questions to ask yourself include:

;
    ;
  • ;Is the company providing me benefits and development opportunities that will enhance my career and life?
    • ;
  • ;Are the company's policies inclusive of my specific needs?
    • ;
  • ;Is the company recognizing the value I'm bringing with more money, a promotion, partnership, or some other important recognition that matters to me?
    • ;
;

;Every company-employee relationship is about loyalty and commitment on both sides, not just achieving goals and collecting a paycheck.

;

;A cult-like atmosphere

;

;When you join a company, everyone is working toward a common mission or goal. If the company has a righteous mission such as helping people be healthy, successful, happy, or helping to sustain the earth, then employees feel like they're contributing to the greater good of humanity or the world. Deciding to leave the company can feel selfish or even traitorous, like you've “given up” on the collective mission.

;

;Even if the company isn't making big impacts on people or the world, the inside atmosphere is about collaborating to achieve a goal together. That feeling of being a critical part of a team or feeling “strong” because you can withstand any suffering to achieve the goals becomes addictive and diminishes the damaging aspects of the job.

;

;When I worked as a TV news reporter, when someone left the business to move into PR or another field, everyone talked about them as giving up or not being able to “cut it.” But the person who left knew they were escaping long hours, working weekends and holidays, low pay for extraordinary effort, and stressful daily deadlines. They were seeking more for their life in alignment with their values.

;

;What to do about it

;

;If you're feeling an intense camaraderie that prevents you from leaving what you know is an unhealthy work environment, take some time to define your what's important to you and determine whether those values are being fulfilled in the job — separate from the company's needs.

;

;Here are some questions to ask yourself to make that determination:

;
    ;
  • ;What's important to me at work, and how do I define what that means?
    • ;
  • ;Which values are being consistently honored or violated?
    • ;
  • ;Is there anything I can do to ensure my values are honored?
    • ;
;

;For example, if being respected is a value and you define it as having your ideas heard and considered, but your manager consistently talks over you or ignores your ideas, your value is being violated. Can you discuss with your manager why this value is so important to you and influence it being honored? If not, you'll need to decide whether the company mission is more important than your values.

;

;Nostalgia for what the company was

;

;When you join a company and have a great experience for months or even years, you're fully engaged in your job. Then change happens, whether that be a new leader, new structure, or a shift in strategic direction, and you may struggle to cope with it.

;

;These kinds of organizational changes can result in feelings of shock, denial, frustration, and depression. If you find yourself struggling to accept and adjust to the changes over time and find yourself saying, “I don't want to leave because I really love the company” instead of “I don't want to leave because I love my job,” then you may be stuck in the past, hoping the company will revert to what it once was.

;

;What to do about it

;

;Change is hard, so give yourself time to adjust and process what it means for your job. After you've accepted the change, take an objective look at whether the present situation still fulfills your values and career goals. If you're still struggling in your job post-change, consider the following questions:

;
    ;
  • ;What was the company like when I joined, and what is the company reality today?
    • ;
  • ;What would make the environment better for me?
    • ;
  • ;Can I make any additional changes or requests to fulfill the values that are no longer being fulfilled?
    • ;
;

;Companies, teams, and leaders all change — often especially as companies grow. It's up to you to determine whether you want to live in the present reality or a past that no longer exists.

;

;Equity handcuffs

;

;Some employees receive equity grants in a company, such as RSUs or stock options. Stock grants vest over a period of time, usually years. Therefore, after suffering a distressing work environment, you may feel even more strongly that you deserve to wait out that vest for what you've been through. But how much trauma are you willing to endure? Waiting for equity to vest could be detrimental to your health, so it's critical to understand whether it's worth it.

;

;What to do about it

;

;Determine exactly when and how much you will receive from each vest at the current stock prices and ask your broker or accountant these questions if you can't figure out the answers:

;
    ;
  • ;After taxes and option strike price payments, how much will I receive?
    • ;
  • ;If I walk away from this money or wait until my stock vest, will this impact my retirement outlook?
    • ;
  • ;What net amount would I need to earn in compensation at another company to make up for the unvested stock value?
    • ;
;

;Equity incentives are granted to keep you in the job, and many companies offer additional grants during your tenure through compensation programs. Therefore, there's never a “final” vesting date. But you can break the never-ending vest cycle if you have an exit date in mind based on how much you want vested before you depart and how much you're willing to forfeit.

;

;Fear

;

;There's no shortage of things to fear when it comes to making a job change: Fear you'll jump into another tough situation, that you'll have to prove yourself all over again, that you won't be able to make as much money. Fear that you don't even know how to look for a job. If you're feeling beaten down from a bad work situation, fear can leave you with little confidence that making a change will lead to a better work environment.

;

;What to do about it

;

;To help you bypass your fears, instead of just dreaming about what your life could look like in a positive work environment, deliberately visualize it. Close your eyes and consider the following when trying to combat negative thoughts and fears:

;
    ;
  • ;If I weren't scared to leave, what would be possible?
    • ;
  • ;What does my new work environment look like, smell like, feel like?
    • ;
  • ;What kind of support do I need to feel more confident in making a change?
    • ;
;

;Finally, think about what advice you would give a close friend about a work situation that mirrors your own.

;

;. 。 .

;

;Leaving a bad job is never easy, and each person's breaking point is different, so beating yourself up over why you stayed so long in a traumatic situation won't help. But learning from each experience will empower you to own your career choices and leave earlier if you find yourself in a comparable situation again.

;;By Joel Raper;

;

;Imagine starting a new job where digital interfaces replace the comfort of friendly introductions and in-person guidance. Many who are now working in hybrid or remote roles have already experienced it.

;

;The hybrid digital workplace is rewriting the rules of onboarding. While a hybrid model offers the flexibility to work from anywhere, it also brings the challenge of creating a cohesive and inclusive experience for new hires.

;

;The essence of onboarding, once a straightforward process of on-site training sessions, device provisioning, and team lunches, now faces a transformative era. Without the nuances of face-to-face interactions, new employees can sometimes feel isolated, trying to make sense of the company's culture, human resources (HR) workflows, and technology tools all while working literally outside a traditional workplace environment.

;

;To address these challenges, organizations are transforming their onboarding strategies. HR and IT leaders emphasize creating robust digital onboarding platforms; integrating team-building activities suitable for remote settings; and ensuring that every new hire feels connected, valued, and equipped to thrive in their new role, even without a physical presence.

;

;;Tailored Solutions for Diverse Needs;

;

;Onboarding today is more than just handing out new laptops. The process begins before an employee's first day, offering them the opportunity to select equipment and familiarize themselves with company culture, enabling immediate connections with other employees and new hires.

;
;
;
; ;
;
;
;

;Beyond an introduction to company values and processes, however, modern onboarding offers an entirely tailored—or persona-based—experience, often involving digital platforms customized for every new hire, directing them to vital resources and fostering connections. Simultaneously, a persona-based approach includes specialized technologies, trainings, and resources that align with distinct job roles.

;

;;Examples of Persona-Based Onboarding;

;

;Remote software developer:

;
    ;
  • ;Preselected tech stack tutorials reinforcing standard coding procedures and access to code repositories.
    • ;
  • ;Virtual coffee breaks with current team members.
    • ;
  • ;One-on-one virtual mentoring sessions with a team leader in order to establish alignment with the company's coding best practices.
    • ;
;

;Regional sales manager for a territory far from corporate headquarters:

;
    ;
  • ;Office tour and team meet-and-greets via augmented reality technology.
    • ;
  • ;Immediate inclusion in hybrid sales meetings and client interaction simulations.
    • ;
  • ;An established on-site “buddy” to partner with during the first week.
    • ;
;

;Manufacturing associate on the factory floor:

;
    ;
  • ;A mobile app that serves as a one-stop shop for all required HR workflows, accessible at any time.
    • ;
  • ;Remotely deployed device provisioning to enable productivity from day one.
    • ;
  • ;A blend of live in-person trainings for complex tasks and safety policies, and virtual modules with evergreen information and resources.
    • ;
;
;
;
; ;
;
;
;

;Global marketing team member based in the UK:

;
    ;
  • ;Tailored compliance training based on UK regulations.
    • ;
  • ;Time-zone-adjusted virtual town halls.
    • ;
  • ;Localized training content to help them understand market-specific sales strategies.
    • ;
;

;US-based customer support representative:

;
    ;
  • ;Access to customer interaction simulations and CRM
    • ;
  • ;Virtual team-building exercises with US and global support teams.
    • ;
  • ;Cultural sensitivity training designed for a diverse customer base.
    • ;
;

;A successful onboarding process in this landscape recognizes the individuality of each new hire. While every employee requires a solid comprehension of company tools, culture, and objectives, the nuances of their experiences and expectations can vary widely by persona. These idiosyncrasies intersect to create custom onboarding experiences, designed as deep dives that align with individual learning styles, demographics, and company roles.

;

;;The Importance of Dynamic Tools;

;

;So how can HR and line-of-business managers begin to understand each relevant onboarding persona and their respective needs?

;

;You don't need to start from scratch—digital experience management tools and their insights are pivotal in shaping personalized onboarding experiences during the first 90 days of employment. Organizations can craft journeys that resonate with each persona by aggregating device performance feedback with employee engagement and sentiment metrics.

;

;In this environment, the goal is consistent: to ensure each newcomer feels seamlessly integrated and satisfied. Through iterative feedback loops and adaptive platforms, the onboarding experience becomes a journey that keeps refining itself.

;

;Such a proactive stance doesn't only cater to immediate onboarding needs. It also positions companies at the cutting edge, crafting a digital workplace experience that's truly inclusive and primed for productivity in the long term.

;

;;A Balanced Approach ;

;

;Yet amidst all this technology and data-driven personalization, organizations must not lose sight of the human essence of onboarding. The challenge—and indeed, the opportunity—lies in seamlessly weaving together the digital and the human (the “phygital”). Achieving this balance could involve virtual team-building activities, mentorship opportunities, or collaborative projects designed to foster a sense of community and connection.

;

;The hybrid digital workplace requires balancing digital solutions' scalability and personal connections' intimacy. By embracing persona-based onboarding solutions, you can help ensure that every employee begins their journey with a sense of purpose, belonging, and excitement, regardless of where they work.

;

;;The Future of Hybrid Onboarding;

;

;The hybrid workplace combines the best of both worlds: the opportunity for purposeful in-person collaboration and remote flexibility. The challenge lies in preserving the personal touch and ensuring that employees feel connected and valued, no matter where they are located. This blended model necessitates an evolved approach to onboarding, one that's persona-based, inclusive, and engaging.

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 00:25:03 +0800 E-Commerce Platforms Must Prioritize the Consumer-Influencer Relationshiphttps://hbr.org/2023/09/e-commerce-platforms-must-prioritize-the-consumer-influencer-relationship
; ;
; ;
; ;ThomasVogel/Getty Images;
;
; ;
; ;Summary.   ; ;

;In China, content-based platforms are generating a growing proportion of e-commerce, presenting a growing threat to established platforms like Alibaba and JD.com.  In this model, consumers buy products during their engagement with the content provider. Managing the platform to generate sales, therefore, is about enabling the right content to reach the right viewers. Savvy content-based platforms are leveraging AI to this trend and carefully curate their influencer relationships. Are the big retail platforms ready for this new model?

; ;
;
;
;
;
; ;Leer en español;
; ;Ler em português;
;

;In September 2021, a mother started posting daily conversations with her two daughters on the Douyin platform (a sister app to TikTok, a ByteDance company). These included funny arguments and real conflicts, in the tone of conversations between a mother and a princess in the harem of an ancient Chinese emperor. (You can get there via WeChat — channels — search for account Wuli瑜的琳姐).

;

;;The videos; resonated with so many parents and children that they quickly amassed a lot of followers (now 2.5M on Douyin). They were contacted by tea merchants, and they began selling tea on live streams;,; with the “buy” click right at the bottom of the screen. The tea was inexpensive, they could interact and communicate, and their fans liked to buy it despite the fact that the tea had nothing to do with the content of their short videos.

;

;;

;

;As a result of these kinds of impulse buys, Douyin has in just two years gone from nothing to a gross merchandise value (GMV) of 1.2 trillion RMB by 2022, with an annual growth rate of 75%, while a similar app, Kuaishou, has reached a GMV of 0.7 trillion RMB in 2022.  ;These numbers; contrast starkly with results at “traditional” platforms such as Alibaba and Jingdong (JD.com), where GMV declined by 1.1% and 8.8%, respectively, in 2022. Moreover, in the livestream content e-retailing segment, Douyin and Kuaishou have already captured two-thirds of the market in 2021 and will reach an even larger share.

;

;;User Behavior Is Changing;

;

;The big incumbent platforms are worried. Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma ;warned at a recent internal meeting; that Alibaba's core e-commerce group is facing very severe competition and that without innovative measures it may now be like Nokia on the eve of its mobile phone collapse. And the company is in the throes of a radical ;restructuring;, reorganizing into six independent business units, each with its own CEOs and boards of directors. Its traditional rival, JD.com, has recently replaced its top team (including the CEO), flattened its organizational structure, and reshaped its strategy to focus on price, quality, and service.

; ; ;
; ;
;
; Insight Center Collection
;

;The New Age of Operations

;
; Improving efficiency and increasing resilience.
;
; ;
; ; ;

;Alibaba and JD are right to be worried, because the likes of Douyin are offering something new. In the traditional shelf-based e-commerce model, users only log on to e-commerce platforms such as Alibaba and JD.com when they have an active shopping need, search for the desired product in the search box, and get product recommendations in order to complete the order.

;

;However, in the content-based model of short-video platforms such as Douyin and Kuaishou, the provider produces a large amount of interesting video content while hanging the relevant SKUs on the little yellow cart below the content. Interacting with the content, users experience resonance and build emotional attachments, which feel like friendship or even love, generating a motivation to buy. In this approach, customers buy for engagement and fun rather than to fulfill a need — because the product resonates with the content they are viewing or because they are fans of certain influencers. And if they realize after the purchase that the item is not something they actually need, they still feel satisfied by the experience.

;

;What's more, people only have a fixed amount of time to spend online each day, and they are spending more and more of it on short videos/live streaming. According to ;a new data.ai; survey, people spend on average four to five hours on content browsing of this kind, with TikTok taking up half of this time. The necessary consequence is that they spend less and less time browsing and buying products on traditional e-commerce platforms.

;

;;Going Beyond Network Effects;

;

;In some respects, the economics of the two models is identical. In both cases, user traffic is the basis for conversion into actual transactions, and to some extent, it determines market size and growth potential. But the similarities end there.

;

;On traditional shelf-based platforms, the fundamental power source for the platform provider is network effects: basically, its ability to connect many providers and many consumers. Success mainly depends on how many providers do business on the platform and the number and types of goods offered, which itself is influenced by the number of consumers showing up. This largely explains why the big platforms were also the early movers.

;

;In the new content-based e-retailing model, however, platforms take on an active role in generating user curiosity and interest through providing attractive, creative, and emotional content. Almost all this content is produced by individuals or SMEs, some of whom become influential by accident and whose success is hard to predict (and may wane). In most cases, the new commercial platforms did not foresee that this influencer content business model would emerge.

;

;To be sure, platforms have always made money from advertising. But advertising has limits; too many ads can make users feel uncomfortable and prompt them to leave. Their success only took off after influencers started to become product ambassadors, turning the emotional relationships they have with their followers into direct revenues for the companies they represent.

;

;This revenue potential is very large. Take the case of New Oriental Education, which had long been China's largest English-language training school, serving students studying abroad for qualifying exams and improving their language skills. Two years ago, ;the school laid off 60,000 employees; and saw its operating revenue plummet by 80% when the Chinese government banned for-profit tutoring.

;

;In order to survive, founder Yu Minhong started selling agricultural products on Douyin, but as his sales staff were all former English teachers who knew little about agricultural products, the venture looked doomed from the outset.

;

;But Yu soon realized that one thing his staff could do was tell stories, and one of them, Dong Yuhui, has turned out to be an online star. He appears in the live-stream room sharing nuggets of history and reciting his favorite poems, offering short reflections and homilies on daily life. (He can be seen also ;on YouTube;). Users love it.They chat with him on the platform and eagerly buy the products he recommends. With daily turnover ranging up to 35 million RMB, the new venture has been a huge success, and has become a separately listed company (HK.1797) called East Buy Holdings, with a current market cap of US$5 billion.

;

;;How the New Platforms Compete;

;

;As the new sector matures, smart platforms are finding ways to help their influencers succeed, most basically by providing the sales process, (ie, the shopping basket). More important, though, is the potential for leveraging AI to channel content of interest to individual users, thereby increasing users' time spent on the platform.

;

;;A case in point; is provided by ;TikTok's short video content;, which stores second-by-second updates of what users watched, clicked on, how long they stayed on which content, and how many screens they visited. This enables it to precisely predict what users will want to watch next. AI-based platform support can also help the influencer sharpen his or her recommendations.

;

;By leveraging tools like this, content-based platforms can significantly increase their commission and advertising revenues, as the influencers on their sites draw more and more traffic away from the traditional online marketplaces. But sustaining success with this model in the long run will require the content-based platform to evolve further. Rather than representing just an intermediary for many providers and consumers, platforms must learn to manage the relationship between influencers and their followers. This will involve making fast transitions from waning influencers to new upcoming ones without letting revenues dip in between.

;

;Not everyone will succeed in evolving, and as the sector matures, we can expect many sites to disappear and new ones to emerge. And while the jury is still out, there are also legitimate concerns about the the effect of these new business models on the health of the general population, which may lead to stricter regulation of their use.

;

;. 。 .

;

;What Douyin is doing in China, other platforms will likely introduce in the US — although the consumers in the two countries are not identical, there is nothing that says that the new emotional relationship between consumers and influencers cannot lead to direct sales in the US as well. The question is: Will US e-commerce platforms ignore the threat or find ways to embrace this new model?

; Wed, 20 Sep 2023 22:25:04 +0800 Leading Change May Need to Begin with Changing Yourselfhttps://hbr.org/2023/09/leading-change-may-need-to-begin-with-changing-yourself
; ;
; ;
; ;Richard Drury/Getty Images;
;
; ;
; ;Summary.   ; ;

;Behavior change is hard, but it’sa skill leaders who want to succeed amid near-constant organizational change need to develop. By increasing their self-awareness, committing to change, overcoming limiting thoughts, and deliberately practicing new behaviors, leaders raise the likelihood that the change initiatives they’re tasked to lead will be successful.

; ;
;
;
;
;
; ;Leer en español;
; ;Ler em português;
;

;Organizational change requires leaders to pivot to new priorities, delegate old ones, and shift the way they interact with their teams. Over the past 30 years of consulting, teaching, and coaching, however, I've found that leaders often pay little attention to how they'll develop the specific behaviors required to lead organizational change, potentially derailing new initiatives.

;

;It makes sense that leaders would rely on the behaviors that got them to where they are in the first place. But to be successful at leading change, they must learn to recognize and act when it's necessary to evolve their own behaviors.

;

;Peter lost his job as CEO because the transformation project he was leading didn't deliver results. Naomi wasn't promoted when her attempts at changing her new company's culture took longer than anticipated. Youssef almost left the company he had been with for his entire career because of what he perceived as a misalignment in values.

;

;Each explained their suboptimal experiences differently. Peter said that poor market conditions in his country rendered the company's revenue projections infeasible. Naomi thought that a hot job market in her country caused higher-than-expected turnover on her team, slowing culture change. Youssef blamed the more transactional values of the younger generation of leaders he worked with for his inability to fit in.

;

;All three, however, didn't realize how they had contributed to their own problems.

;

;To succeed, Peter needed to focus solely on reducing organizational inefficiencies, leaving revenue in the hands of his sales lead. This new division of labor worked until they lost a major deal. That prompted Peter to get involved with sales again, reducing his attention on inefficiencies, and the organization fell behind on both sales and efficiency targets.

;

;Naomi was hired to transform the culture of her new team from a bureaucratic, order-filling mindset to an agile, customer-responsive one. She knew she could only do this by listening to and assuaging her team's concerns about the changes. Yet, facing high turnover, her patience flagged, and she reverted to more directive leadership, causing even more turnover.

;

;Youssef took a country manager's position in his company to move closer to his extended family. He had previously held a more senior global role in the company. He didn't mind the lower compensation and felt grateful that the company allowed him flexibility. However, he didn't stop to think about how he would need to behave with new superiors who were younger and less experienced than him.

;

;Changing Behavior Is a Process

;

;Peter, Naomi, and Youssef all failed to pay attention to how they needed to change their own behavior. Peter and Naomi needed to change in order to successfully execute transformation projects. Youssef needed to adapt to a new role.

;

;Changing behavior can be hard, as anyone who has tried it can attest. This article outlines a four-step process to help you change your behavior when needed. I've used this successfully with both leaders and teams in my private practice and in multiple executive programs.

;

;Step 1: Increase Your Self-Awareness

;

;Leaders can only change their behavior when they're aware of how it's perceived by others and of the thoughts and feelings they experience as they attempt to change.

;

;Peter had been unaware that his board suggested he focus on cost efficiencies because they perceived him to be the bottleneck in the sales process. Had he known, he might have reconsidered stepping back into sales.

;

;Losing his job shook Peter. “I don't want that to happen again,” he said to me as he contemplated future job opportunities. “When times were good, I used to ask my team for feedback on my behavior. When things got tough, I stopped. I told myself I was too busy. Maybe I didn't want to hear what I subconsciously knew they would say to me.”

;

;Peter was making two important observations about self-awareness. First, leaders need to regularly seek feedback on how they're perceived, not leave it in the hands of external circumstances. Second, they need to be wary of thoughts and feelings that suggest that feedback is either unnecessary or inappropriate. Noticing such thoughts is the first step to overcoming them.

;

;Step 2: Make Commitments

;

;While awareness of how others perceive us can itself be a change catalyst (hence the saying “the most powerful driver of change is a mirror”), making commitments to others raises the likelihood of success.

;

;Naomi faced a choice when she learned she wouldn't be promoted. She could look for another job, or she could stay, get better at driving culture change, and hope to be promoted in the future. She chose to do the latter.

;

;Naomi felt she jumped to solutions without listening carefully because of her inordinate fear of “wasting time.” She needed help to listen more. So she made a public commitment to her direct reports. “I promise to listen more,” she said. “I think it will help us make changes more effectively. But I need your help.” She asked her team to call her out when she didn't listen.

;

;In the weeks that followed, the memory of her commitment frequently restrained her when she felt the urge to switch to problem-solving. When she did unwittingly bark out a solution, her team members responded by smiling and saying ,“You said you would listen!”

;

;Step 3: Overcome Interference

;

;Despite credible intentions to change, leaders may struggle when they encounter thoughts that derail their intentions.

;

;Youssef's new country manager role was two steps below his previous global marketing role. He prepared by meeting his new boss before taking the job and discussing how they could work together. But he didn't anticipate his reactions to comments from his new colleagues that criticized policies he had previously contributed to.

;

;His boss criticized the company policy requiring all regions to sell a new product, saying it didn't reflect the reality of their region. Youssef reacted defensively because he had previously promoted the policy. “Headquarters understands differences between regions,” he responded, “but they still need to incentivize new product sales. If not, regions might not push these potentially valuable products sufficiently.”

;

;His boss and colleagues felt Youssef was talking down to them. They were struggling to sell expensive new products in their highly price-sensitive region and felt Youssef could be more supportive.

;

;But Youssef's reaction was influenced by thoughts he barely noticed. “I've worked in headquarters and understand corporate strategy better than you,” was one. “How dare you suggest our policies were thoughtless,” was another. Lying just under the surface of his consciousness, these thoughts interfered with his desire to be supportive and evoked unproductive, defensive reactions.

;

;I introduced Youssef to ACT, a mindfulness-based cognitive therapy, and showed him how he could “defuse” his thoughts. A simple way to do this is by closing your eyes and imagining you're looking at a thought as if it's appearing on a screen in front of you. The thought that seemed to trigger Youssef the most was “I understand this company's values better than you.”

;

;By defusing this and related thoughts, Youssef was able to create a gap between comments that provoked him and his reaction, making for more productive conversations. From coming close to wanting to quit, Youssef found himself instead evolving into the role of a mentor for younger colleagues who wanted to learn from his experience at headquarters — all thanks to mitigating the effects of thoughts he had barely noticed before.

;

;Step 4: Practice

;

;Rarely do leaders find they can set a personal change objective, choose a path, and execute with no trouble. Successful change usually arises from trial and error, which takes deliberate practice. Leaders do better when they practice small, needed changes deliberately, learning from the experience, rather than aiming for a big bang of all needed changes.

;

;Naomi knew that listening to her team was just one of several new behaviors she needed to adopt. She also needed to stop micromanaging, delegate more, and give her team greater agency. She knew she would find these behaviors difficult, so she practiced small changes periodically.

;

;She might begin a team meeting with a quick round of issues that team members would like to bring to the table, or ask a team member to lead a meeting instead of her. These little changes offered her opportunities to learn not just how the team functioned but also how she would react. Over time, Naomi and her team converged on a working pattern more conducive to the cultural changes her company wanted to see.

;

;. 。 .

;

;Behavior change is hard, but it's a skill leaders who want to succeed amid near-constant organizational change need to develop. By increasing their self-awareness, committing to change, overcoming limiting thoughts, and deliberately practicing new behaviors, leaders raise the likelihood that the change initiatives they're tasked to lead will be successful.

;
; ;
; ;摘要。   ; ;

;当今的领导者知道他们需要敏捷—面对变化或不确定的情况迅速改变方向。但敏捷性的副产品是流失：许多此类枢轴所带来的混乱和消极情绪。这可能会导致效率低下，从而阻碍创新项目和战略。作者建议领导者应该设定并传达一个不变的总体目标，同时允许他们实现该目标的方式可以并且将会随着时间的推移而改变。

;

; 

; ;

;

; 

; ;

; div>;
;
;
;

;当今最受赞誉的领导特质之一是转变能力——当计划的道路受阻或发现不利时迅速改变方向。这种快速适应，通常被称为;敏捷性;，在快速变化的环境中或在旧行为和管理实践不再有效的未知领域进行创新时至关重要。有些人认为这是一种领导力;超级权力;。

;

;然而，任何领导力超级权力都可能成为弱点。当领导者频繁改变项目方向时，他们的员工可能会对他们应该做什么感到困惑（或者至少需要花时间重新规划和解决变革），从而导致效率低下和流失并阻碍进展。这也会让人失去动力：这就像告诉某人向北跑，然后向南跑，然后向北，然后再向南跑。在多次改变方向后，员工的明智之举是保持原地不动，直到领导者弄清楚。

;

;这个问题的解决方案不能简单地“降低敏捷性”。在这些情况下，面对快速变化的环境和高度的不确定性，领导者基本上都在做正确的事情。他们不会坚持走一条可能导致死胡同或浪费公司时间和资源的道路，而是将团队转向他们认为更有生产力的方向，然后在必要时一次又一次地这样做。< /p>;

;根据我多年为企业提供创新和效率咨询的经验，我相信，为了应对这些变化的负面影响，领导者通过转型引导团队应该更好地区分;手段;和< em>;结束;：他们应该能够阐明一个最终目标，即使实现目标的手段发生变化，该目标也保持不变。

;

;让我们看两个例子。在我建议的一家科技企业中，创始人通过大量实验和即兴创作创造了他的核心产品，尝试了一项又一项，直到弄清楚什么是有效的。然而，随着公司发展到拥有 100 多名工程师和多个项目团队，所有项目团队均以原始产品设计为基础，创始人不断即兴创作和改变方向的愿望更多地成为一种负担，而不是一种优势。一位经理将这种效果描述为一种瘫痪，每个人都只是等待下一条指令。 “没有人愿意采取任何主动行动，”她说，“因为无论我们做什么都可能会改变。”

;

;这种过度敏捷的动态对于小型初创公司和大公司来说都是一个问题。几年前，我与一家价值数十亿美元的个人护理公司合作，该公司进行了三项中型收购，以实现产品组合多元化。由于这些收购中的每一项都包含知名品牌，首席执行官计划让它们作为全资但独立的实体运营。但几个月后，在董事会要求从收购中获取更多协同价值的压力下，他改变了方针，要求公司职能部门（人力资源、财务等）将被收购实体的流程和系统与被收购实体的流程和系统保持一致。核心公司。但事实证明，让公司所有职能部门的人员涌入被收购的公司会造成破坏，因此他后来退缩了，并告诉公司职能部门只选择一两个系统进行标准化。此时，被收购实体的管理者完全不知道其所有者真正想要什么，并告诉员工在事情变得清晰之前不要采取任何行动。

;

;在此处引用的两个案例中，以及在许多其他过度敏捷的情况下，领导者过于关注实现目标的手段，以至于他们（及其团队）失去了对最终结果的关注。在这家科技初创公司中，创始人希望通过实验揭示新产品的机会，但没有明确说明他对下一代产品的愿景。在缺乏清晰的产品愿景的情况下，所有可能性都是有效的。同样，在个人护理公司，首席执行官从未阐明整合新收购公司的总体目标。事实上，他似乎是一边做一边弥补，并根据投资者、团队和被收购公司经理的反应改变目标。难怪这会在需要执行的人员中产生混乱。

;

;这里的好消息是，一旦领导者意识到，过度关注“手段”而忽视“目的”的情况是可以纠正的这就是正在发生的事情。这是目标设定和沟通的问题。在这家科技公司，创始人最终从他的团队收到了强烈的反馈，即不断的工程变化意味着团队不确定他们应该做什么。作为回应，他与团队合作，为下一个产品的外观创建参数，然后给团队留出更多空间来弄清楚如何实现这一目标。如今，团队的工作效率更高，并且对他们正在开发具有商业可行性的新产品充满信心。

;

;在个人护理公司，首席执行官意识到公司没有达到预期目标考虑到收购的投资回报率，要求业务发展负责人对公司应该如何整合新公司做了一个简短的研究。一个关键结论是，收购后的每个实体都应该有一个更具体的目标和愿景，然后整合团队将有权找到实现该目标的正确途径。此方法随后应用于这三起收购中。

;

;例如，其中一家被收购公司在特定产品类别中拥有强大的市场份额和品牌知名度，因此团队制定的目标是加速该类别的发展生长。然而，在整合过程的早期，团队意识到，如果他们继续强迫每个人都遵循新所有者的流程和方法，他们将面临失去收购带来的大部分人才的危险。这将使增长目标陷入危险，因为该团队的经验对于该类别的成功是必要的。于是他们改变了方向：他们没有将收购并入母公司，而是采取了“反向收购”的方式，即母公司的一些人员向被收购公司的管理团队汇报。但最终目标——在核心类别中取得更大成功——保持不变。经理们不再感到困惑或士气低落，最终这个新部门超出了早期设想的增长预期。

;

;。 。 .

;

;如果你正在参与一个项目，或者正在领导一个项目，而这个项目似乎经常因为改变路线而被打乱，那么请退后一步，问以下问题：我们是否清楚我们的最终目标——我们需要实现的结果——我们是否觉得我们的改变让我们更接近这个目标？如果答案不是明确的“是”，那么您可能需要更好地定义和传达您的目标，以便您的敏捷性不会妨碍您的效率。

;作为数以百万计的小企业在大流行期间开设了新的在线店面，一组在幕后辛勤工作的技术使所有这些网站以及销售和交付成为可能。

;

;这些技术中最重要的一个，也许也是最重要的技术之一默默无闻的是身份验证。该软件已经存在了几十年，可以证明您就是您所说的那样。每次您在线购物时（这种情况每天在世界各地发生数十亿次），身份验证系统都会对您进行身份验证。

;

;如果没有这个简单的概念，数字经济就无法运行。所有这些新的数字化企业，从时装设计师到面包店，都无法区分他们的客户和诈骗者。

;

;当然，有很多种身份验证系统，这些技术将成为随着数字经济的发展，这一点变得更加重要。需要身份识别工具来继续应对网络攻击和在线诈骗的增加。它们将使人们能够更快、更轻松地在线访问所需的内容。在电子商务网站上购物、访问政府服务、管理资金——在许多国家/地区，所有这些活动都需要进行身份验证。

;

;但随着身份验证工具变得越来越重要，它也将变得同样重要让任何需要它们的人都可以使用它们。数百万人无法使用数字工具。如果他们无法在线验证自己的身份，他们就会被排除在外。寻找更多方法为小型企业提供身份验证并为消费者提供数字身份，将为数百万人提供更多机会，并使数字经济更具活力、更具包容性和更安全。

;

;这就是我们的愿景 - 使用这项技术使数字经济像当地农贸市场或咖啡店一样充满活力和热情。

;

;;什么是身份验证？;

;

;其核心，身份验证工具可证明您的信息（姓名、地址、年龄、电话号码）有效且与您相关联。 ;许多不同的技术;可用于实现这一目标。

;

;最常见的技术之一是身份验证验证软件，正如我之前提到的。例如，它可用于验证电子商务网站上的购买情况。该软件可证明您的 ID 正在使用您的登录名、密码和设备 IP 地址等数据，而无需您输入任何新信息。例如，Mastercard Identity 与旅游网站 FlightHub 合作，实时评估数百万笔在线预订，并与 Greenwood Bank 合作，确保吸引真正的客户。

;

;该技术的其他形式包括智能 ID 卡，内置芯片的物理卡可以存储您的身份证或医疗信息。您的手机上还可以保存驾驶执照或护照的数字版本。

;

;最后，Apple ID 和 Google Identity 等 ID 管理系统提供了一组您可以使用的登录凭据许多网站和服务。

;

;许多国家政府都大力依赖这项技术来实现服务现代化和数字化。最先进的国家之一是;爱沙尼亚;，它为每个公民提供国家发行的电子身份证他们可以使用物理智能卡、移动应用程序或网站访问身份。这些电子身份证可用于购物、支付账单、签署合同、访问医疗记录，甚至在线投票。

;

;新加坡的 ;Singpass; 国民身份证应用程序可让人们连接到政府服务和许多企业。它使用生物识别指纹或面部验证，使人们能够在银行、食品配送和保险等各种数字活动中验证自己的身份。

;

;该领域的另一个主要参与者是印度，该国运营着全球最大的数字身份平台，称为 ;Aadhaar;。公民可以使用二维码分享他们的身份信息，二维码保存在移动应用程序中，或者保存在实体纸质卡或塑料卡的背面。数以百万计的印度人已经使用 Aadhaar 在银行和移动电话提供商处开设新账户，访问他们以前无法获得的数字服务。

;

;万事达卡与印度和新加坡合作，确保这些 ID 系统的安全，确保人们的数据受到保护。

;

;;数字包容之路;

;

;正如我们在印度所看到的，身份验证已迅速成为一种强大的工具传播数字和金融包容性。一旦有人可以在数字空间中分享他们安全且经过身份验证的身份，就会为他们带来更多机会。仍然需要做更多的事情，;全球有 8.5 亿人;没有任何正式的身份证件（数字或其他形式）。

;

;一项旨在增加对身份证件工具的使用的小规模但有希望的努力正在发生德克萨斯州奥斯汀。在那里，;戴尔医学院;正在开发一个新平台，帮助无家可归的人找回自己的身份。

;

;在许多情况下，这些人的身份证件被盗，这使得找回身份变得困难让他们获得基本服务，例如政府援助和药物。这还导致他们在去医院时反复被误诊，因为提供者没有他们的病史，并且每次就诊时往往必须从头开始。

;

;戴尔医疗团队为人们创造了一种方法使用手机的生物识别技术（如指纹）验证他们的 ID。 (;研究人员注意到;美国大多数无家可归者都拥有智能手机，将其用作获取所需资源并与朋友和家人保持联系的重要工具。）他们的 ID 可以在线或在他们的手机，数据使用分散的区块链分类账存储，因此不会丢失或被黑客攻击。至关重要的是，用户控制着自己的数据，并且必须明确同意共享数据。

;

;该项目仍在开发中，但表明身份验证有望带来更广泛的社会效益。

;

; ;潜在陷阱;

;

;当然，技术只是故事的一部分。

;

;虽然 ID 工具在世界许多地方被广泛采用，< a href="https://www.aclu.org/news/privacy-technology/digital-ids-might-sound-like-a-good-idea-but-they-could-be-a-privacy-nightmare" >;有些人担心某些形式;的数字身份证，例如驾驶执照的虚拟版本，可能会导致您的所有互动和交易在未经您同意的情况下被记录和监控。

;

;情况总是如此由于拥有宝贵的个人信息，许多人还对创建一个可以存储所有身份和健康数据的集中位置表示担忧，这为黑客创造了一个诱人的目标。

;

;必须使用身份验证来增强人们的能力建立对数字经济的信任——而不是削弱它。做到这一点的最佳方法是确保安全性、透明度和消费者隐私是这些技术的核心。我们需要确保人们可以控制他们的数据并批准对其的访问。以正确的方式引导 ID 工具，我们可以确保消费者和小型企业对数字交互的双方都具有信任。

;

;揭开 ID 验证的含义及其使用方式也很重要。爱沙尼亚和新加坡的身份证系统已经存在 20 年，而印度则在 14 年前开始实施。用于信用卡和借记卡交易的 3D 安全身份验证标准更为古老，于 1999 年推出。该技术几十年来已经证明了其价值。

;

;ID 验证可用于增强隐私，而不是剥夺隐私。例如，如果有人需要确认自己的年龄才能购买酒精饮料，他们不需要分享典型驾驶执照上的所有信息——姓名、年龄、地址、照片。使用身份验证技术，确认将作为一个简单的是或否的问题而存在——这个人是否超过 21 岁？这是人们需要分享的唯一信息。

;

;;展望未来;

;

;我们都看到了 ID 软件在大流行期间的好处- 即使商家无法再面对面见到客户，也能让商业继续进行。继续磨练这项技术将有助于企业发展，并最终为人们和社区建立抵御能力，帮助他们抵御下一次危机。

;

;构建这项技术的工作仍在继续，因为我们很多人都看到了这一前景。 Much more is possible and much more is already happening.
